title: Exeter former drug addict gets his first job in 30 years at homeless hostel | Metro News
text:
Tanveer Mann for Metro.co.uk Monday 27 Feb 2017 1:54 pm John Clarke, 47, a former heroin addict, has started a job at a homeless hostel in Exeter (Picture: BBC Inside Out South West) 
An ex-offender has managed to secure his first job in 30 years after spending most of that time in and out of prison. America to start drug-testing unemployed people before paying benefits 
John Clarke, 47, a former heroin addict, has started a job at a homeless hostel in Exeter after being on benefits for the majority of his life. 
The 47-year-old, who lives in Devon, was addicted to heroin for nearly 25 years, but has been clean for three years. To view this video please enable JavaScript, and consider upgrading to a web browser that supports HTML5 video 
He told the BBC : ‘I was a really nasty person. Most of my time was spent doing criminal activities to fund my drug habit.’ 
But after going off drugs, John’s managed to turn his life around and won himself a short-term contract as a support worker. 
MORE: Anger at families who spent benefits on Botox, smoking and fancy restaurants Clarke spent 30 years on benefits (Picture: BBC Inside Out South West) 
‘My mum is going to die knowing that I got it right. I want her to die proud of me,’ John said. Benefits cheat ‘will have to sell house’ after he was caught doing a paper round 
He’s already been there for three months and has managed to help other people 
He said: ‘No one can say I’m an old bum anymore. I don’t owe no-one nothing, my money that I get, I earn. ‘I’ve turned something that was a real bad negative into a positive.’ (Picture: BBC Inside Out South West) 
‘All the people that have supported me has given me the confidence that actually I’m quite capable. 
‘I’ve turned something that was a real bad negative into a positive.’
